docs.lead_paragraph: In a unanimous vote, the House Commerce Committee today approved a bill intended to guarantee health insurance coverage for millions of Americans who switch jobs or lose jobs each year. The measure will be bundled together wit legislation from three other House committees. The chief deputy whip for House Republicans, Representative Dennis Hastert of Illinois, said the full House would probably vote on the package next Thursday.

headline.main: House Panel O.K.'s Bill Assuring Health Care in Job Switches

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a broad plan today intended to lower health care costs by lifting most of the rules that control the fees charged by hospitals. He also called for the state to make deep cuts in financing for medical education, a proposal that quickly ran into opposition in New York City, where programs that train doctors are one of the pillars of care in poor neighborhoods.

headline.main: PATAKI IS SEEKING TO END REGULATION OF HOSPITAL RATES

docs.lead_paragraph: TAMMY FAYE BAKKER MESSNER'S second husband, ROE MESSNER, was sentenced to 27 months in Federal prison for bankruptcy fraud. After the sentencing in Wichita, Kan., Mr. Messner's lawyer revealed that Mrs. Messner was undergoing treatment for colon cancer. "They had to do a very fast surgery," the lawyer, Steve Joseph, said after Mr. Messner, 60, was sentenced in Federal District Court, The Associated Press reported. A judge also ordered Mr. Messner, a contractor, to pay more than $72,000 in restitution.

docs.lead_paragraph: Caremark International Inc. will spend $65.6 million to settle disputes with insurers arising from a Government fraud investigation of kickbacks that the company, a health services concern, paid physicians for patient referrals. The settlement announced yesterday "resolves good-faith business disputes" stemming from the investigation and is not an admission of wrongdoing, said C. A. Lance Piccolo, Caremark's chairman and chief executive. The money will be deducted from Caremark's 1996 first-quarter profits. It is more than three times the $21.4 million Caremark earned in the first quarter of last year. Caremark, based in Northbrook, Ill., pleaded guilty last year to Federal fraud charges and agreed to pay $161 million in civil and criminal fines.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR much of his adult life, Sam Di blasi, a 54-year-old warehouse worker, has been lifting heavy loads. Last June, on Mutual of Omaha's corporate campus in downtown Omaha, he found himself inside a familiar stone warehouse dressed in sneakers, a T-shirt and sweat pants. Instead of commanding his forklift, Mr. Diblasi, troubled by a bad back and a soaring cholesterol count, was lifting something even more challenging: two 50-pound dumbbells.

headline.main: Instilling the Workout Ethic at Work

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill today that would guarantee access to health insurance for many people who switch jobs or lose their jobs, and Republican leaders said they hoped to take the measure to the House floor next week. The vote to approve the bill was 25 to 11, with Republicans supporting it and most Democrats opposing it. Those Democrats objected to certain provisions of the bill, particularly tax incentives for the creation of private savings accounts to help pay medical expenses.

docs.lead_paragraph: DIET and fitness books have a new look: many now come with phone numbers offering products for sale that are supposed to help the dieter lose weight painlessly, whether it's by eating too few carbohydrates or too many, too little protein or too much, too little fat or too much. So now the authors are making money not only from book royalties but also from the sale of nutrition bars that can replace meals, supplements to increase athletic performance and even a face cream to reduce cancer-causing free radicals. After spending $20 or $30, readers put their faith in the programs, and many are eager to buy anything that may make it easier to lose weight.

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation fell 14 percent yesterday on news the nursing home chain was being investigated for possible billing fraud by the Justice Department and the Department of Health and Human Services. The company had said late on Friday that the investigation involved about $3.4 million in Medicare and related co-insurance billings for services provided by facilities formerly operated by Greenery Rehabilitation Group Inc., a rehabilitation concern that Horizon acquired in early 1994. Horizon said it would record a charge of $5.1 million, or about 6 cents a share, for the quarter that ended Feb. 29. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Horizon fell $2.375, to $13.875.

headline.main: DISCLOSURE OF FRAUD INQUIRY HITS HORIZON/CMS STOCK

docs.lead_paragraph: After promises from everyone that this year would be different, New York State is heading toward a new fiscal year in two weeks without a budget. If anything, Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature are playing a more ambitious game of fiscal maneuvering than Albany has seen in a long time, as all sides try to draw Washington into a contest over who should get the blame for the state's budget problems. The latest game-playing occurred on Friday, when Mr. Pataki announced that he had "found" $1.4 billion in additional money to balance the budget next year without new spending cuts. It was more an act of prestidigitation than discovery, however. The money materialized because of a series of new assumptions that tax revenues were going to be greater than earlier projected, and that expenses on welfare, Medicaid and other spending programs would be less. The Governor also wants to tap $350 million from a surplus in a fund set aside to pay medical malpractice awards, which would require legislative approval and is opposed by doctors and the insurance industry.

headline.main: Budgetary Sleight of Hand in Albany
